abstract.p: American Institute of Certified Public Accountants president Barry C Melancon letter on July 18 article opposes Securities and Exchange Commission proposal to limit services offered by accounting firms

block.p: Re ''Unbiased Accounting'' (editorial, July 18): As you acknowledge, there is no evidence that non-audit work by accounting firms has led to any impropriety.
Re ''Unbiased Accounting'' (editorial, July 18): As you acknowledge, there is no evidence that non-audit work by accounting firms has led to any impropriety.

Indeed, a recent report by the Panel on Audit Effectiveness, formed at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission, concluded that ''both the profession and the quality of audits are fundamentally sound.'' The panel said it could find no evidence that providing non-audit services had hurt audit quality, and in approximately 25 percent of the cases it actually improved audit quality.

The S.E.C.'s proposal to restrict the services offered by accounting firms represents a fundamental restructuring of a profession that has, for the last century, given investors the reliable, independent data they need. A decision to tell some businesses what services they may offer and other businesses from whom they can buy services is an extraordinary economic intervention.
BARRY C. MELANCON President, American Institute of Certified Public Accountants Washington, July 22, 2000
